keyTakeAways: Tzachi Hanegbi has been fired by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as national security adviser, with Gil Reich appointed as acting head of the National Security Council.

Hanegbi's departure follows weeks of speculation over growing tensions between him and Netanyahu, particularly regarding Israel’s military strategy in Gaza and the handling of the October 7 Hamas attack.
Hanegbi called for a thorough investigation into the failures leading to the October 7 attack, admitting shared responsibility, while Netanyahu’s government has not yet established such a commission.
Opposition figures like Gadi Eisenkot criticized the dismissal as an evasion of accountability, arguing it replaces responsible officials with 'yes-men'.
Hanegbi, appointed in 2023, held multiple ministerial roles in public security, intelligence, and regional cooperation, indicating a long-standing influence in Israel's security apparatus.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Israel’s Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has dismissed national security adviser Tzachi Hanegbi, citing internal disagreements over military strategy in Gaza, particularly Hanegbi’s opposition to a full military takeover and his advocacy for a partial deal with Hamas. Hanegbi, who served since 2023, called for a thorough investigation into the failures that led to the October 7, 2023 Hamas attack, admitting shared responsibility, while Netanyahu’s government has not yet established a formal inquiry. In his place, Gil Reich, the deputy head of the National Security Council, has been appointed as acting head. The move has drawn criticism from opposition figures like Gadi Eisenkot, who argue it reflects a broader pattern of political evasion and replacement of accountable officials with loyalists.
title: Israel’s Netanyahu fires national security chief amid Gaza tensions
